newsitem.title: UK: Metals look to autumn as rate cut fails to excite.
newsitem.headline: Metals look to autumn as rate cut fails to excite.

text.p: Metal prices will continue to slumber until the nights start drawing in, after a round of interest rate cuts in Europe failed to excite the market.
Germany's Bundesbank made an above-forecast cut in its repo (securities re-purchase) rate to three pct from 3.3 pct on Thursday, prompting other European central banks to follow.
"It is welcome as the economy is not gaining much strength... but it is symptomatic of how weak the economy is," analyst Robin Bhar of London Metal Exchange (LME) trader Brandeis (Brokers) Ltd said.
"The Bundesbank rate cut was a surprise and is probably the best news that the market has heard for some time...it will be a good stimulus for growth," broker GNI Ltd said in its daily review.
Unsurprisingly, LME prices and sentiment were unmoved by the economic developments, as the non-ferrous metals market is be-devilled by slow summer trading conditions at present.

"In the very short-term it (Buba cut) makes no difference, as nobody wants to take these markets on at the moment. Long-term -- if it feeds through into offtake, then yes it is positive," one trader said.
But even this might take some time to transpire, as the second half of the year is not looking particularly promising so far for metals.
"The European economies will not do much this year...we have a global economy that is chugging along at the bottom. The U.S. is the only bright spot really," said Bhar.
Traders are hoping that the end of the summer lull -- a period when manufacturers run down activities for annual maintainance and holidays -- will bring some interest and turnover back on to the LME.
This is likely to be a few weeks yet, as there are holidays in the UK next Monday and in the U.S. next weekend.
Once these are out of the way end-users will be looking at their likely requirements for the final quarter of 1996.
